transcription.text: (soft music)
- The title of my talk is Scalable Secure Scuttlebutt.
My name is Dominic Tarr.
So what is Scuttlebutt?
So Scuttlebutt,
Scalablebutt is a nautical term for gossip,
a butt is a barrel, that water is stored in,
and scuttle is to open the barrel.
So it's to make a hole in it.
So this way Scuttle is also a disincorship
'cause you open the ship.
So
the,
yeah, so this means gossip for pirates and stuff like this.
So,
and I got the term from
a part of the Amazon paper,
there was an Amazon paper called
Flow Control for Anti-Intropy Projects.
It's like for anti-entropy protocols.
So it's eventually consistent gossip protocol
that's used within a trusted system.
And then I made secure Scuttlebutt,
which took the same idea and then added security.
So the pair,
that idea of the pair is the,
is its public key.
The data model is just append only logs
where each pair,
appends to, has its own personal log that's signed.
Pairs can relay other messages,
but they can't insert, modify, or reorder messages
because the signatures would then be invalid.
So
this gives you like a really simple data model
that can use to re-represent a bunch of stuff,
but it's, and it's completely like free to run like signatures.
You can make 12,
thousands of signatures a second on an ordinary laptop.
You can, the current implementation can receive like 2000 messages
a second and validate them like it's,
it's very like, it's not,
it avoids all kinds of bottlenecks that you do
if you have a consensus layer.
So this,
then there's a few,
it maps quite closely to social media kind of models
like Twitter and whatnot
because you follow the feeds that you want to replicate.
And this solves a whole bunch of neat problems.
So this solves a civil attack because the human,
it bubbles up with the human layer
and then they just unfollow the nodes
they don't want to talk to.
Or don't want to hear from.
It also provides discovery.
So writing a crappy peer to peer Google
would be really, really hard,
but writing a crappy peer to peer social network
actually can still be really awesome
if they're awesome people on it.
And you can still discover new things
so it's a way of like discovering things
in a decentralized way.
And then because it replicates messages in order,
it's easy to think about building a database
on top of this because the things happen.
You receive things in the same order that they happened.
So that was secure, it's got a bug.
And then my recent work has been to make it
much, much more scalable.
So scalable, secure, or scuttlebutt is the same thing again,
but optimized for bandwidth and latency.
So the big deal here is that the overhead,
the networking overhead is proportional
to the feeds updated.
And I'll explain why that's important.
So part one is optimizing the network topology.
So the simplest, most naive design would be
just to connect to everyone.
And I had a really cool animation of this
that you can't see, but perhaps I'll just like,
I don't know, you can see something kind of happening?
Yep.
So this of course is inherently centralized,
it goes out from one point, but it's actually really efficient
because each message is transmitted exactly once
to every node.
So the amount of people that receive messages
is exactly the same as the amount of messages
that are sent.
And but the problem is this means that actually
there's one node that does all the work
and all the other nodes do nearly no work.
And then that's, you know about why centralization is bad.
So another solution is you just have a random network,
just peers, every peer connects to a couple
of other random nodes.
And it's really easy to make a fully connected network
like this.
Like if you connect to more than two peers,
two other peers, the chance of being completely connected
is like, as the network gets bigger, it increases.
So once you pass two, it's like the chance
of being fully connected, it's like pretty much certain.
And but the problem is that it's a trade off
between bandwidth and latency, depending on how many
extra connections you have.
So I have another animation here.
So it's like, looks like a noisy mess.
And then you might see some like red,
all the red messages that are flying around,
those are the extra redundant messages.
And if you have like, I think this one has like five
connections or something, I've got a little table here.
Yeah, so once you have like five connections per things,
then you're getting like 10 times extra redundant messages
that you don't need to send.
Well, you kind of need to send to make sure they arrive,
but you've sent 10 times as much as you needed to.
But it's super robust.
And it's super simple to implement as well.
The role is just sends new messages to everyone
that didn't send it to you, which is also being
don't resend messages you already know.
So just, you say for message, check if you already know
about this message.
And if not, send it to everyone that you're connected to.
And then that will flood the whole network pretty efficiently.
Like, very robustly.
Like if some nodes get taken out, it'll just
be routed around otherwise.
So there's only like a couple of cases
we need to think of here as like one pair sends it
to another pair, or the second pair sends it to the first pair.
And the other thing that can happen
is they both send it to each other,
where there are two paths for that message
to get to Alice and to Bob.
And they both received it within the time
that it takes to send one message.
That's the only case where you get both pairs passing
the message, where you get a redundant connection.
And the bandwidth complexity is like it's proportional
to the messages times the spanning connections
plus twice the redundant connections,
because each redundant connection
gets two messages sent on it.
So the redundant connections are much more expensive
than the minimal set of spanning connections.
And once you've got 10-- when you've got 10 connections
to a pair pair, you have like 95% redundant messages.
So that means if we can get rid of the rounded messages,
we can just transmit one message, one message per pair,
which is optimal.
So the better solution is a spanning tree network.
So a spanning tree is like we get a graph,
and we just only have the connections
we need to reach all of the nodes.
So we can take the flooding gossip,
and we can build-- use that to build a spanning network
in a decentralized way by just whenever you receive
a duplicate message, you just deactivate that connection.
I didn't say disconnect, and I'll come back to that in a bit.
So you just deactivate that.
So now you're sending just the number of messages.
The only problem is that trees are really fragile.
Because now you've basically just added a whole bunch of--
you've made every single node into a central point of failure.
So there's one path between any two random nodes.
And if any of the nodes in that thing fail,
then those messages just won't get through.
So it's bandwidth optimal, but it's not robust.
But then there's this paper I discovered a while ago
called Epidemic Broadcast Trees.
And this combines the best parts of both flooding gossip
and spanning trees.
So how it works, basically, is you have the connections
are in two modes.
There's eager, and there's lazy.
And so the redundant connections get put into lazy mode.
So in eager mode, when you receive a message,
you transmit it immediately.
And when a connection is in lazy mode,
when you receive a message, you just
seem to really short note that you know about this new message
now.
So all of the spanning connections
get the whole message sent across it.
So that lets the message propagate as fast as it can.
And then the redundant connections,
they just have a very short message being sent across.
So it might only be--
so in the current implementation of secure scotter work,
and the average message size is like 700 bytes.
And it could be got to 8 kilobytes.
But the note would only be like 80 bytes, I think.
And that could be binary optimized down
to probably less than 10.
So the redundant connections still exist.
But you just seem to wail your starter on them.
And then they also-- the robustness still exists
because when a message-- so when you receive a message
for the first time, you re-broadcast it and so on.
But if you receive a note about a message
that you don't know about yet, then you send a request back
to that peer asking them to turn back into eager mode.
And then that was the new the whole message.
And now then it works as repaired.
So as the best of both worlds.
Yeah, and then there's only a small amount of state
that you need to keep track of per feed.
You just need the ID, the local sequence number,
the remote sequence number, the local request,
the remote request, and the local and remote modes.
So that's only--
that's under like-- depending on how long the ID string is,
we're talking about just like tens of bytes.
So then the other-- so that's all about optimizing the network.
So the second part is optimizing the handshakes.
So Secure Scuttlebutt had this--
so original Scuttlebutt had this thing called a vector clock.
So a vector clock is just like a list of all of the things.
So you have a whole bunch of friends.
And when two friends bump into each other,
they say, oh, when did you last here from Bob?
I heard from Bob on Tuesday.
When did you last here from Alice?
I heard from Alice on Monday.
And if I say that I saw Alice on Monday
and you saw her on Sunday, then I can--
then I know I just need to send you the messages from Monday.
Or from after Sunday.
So it means we just exchange this one thing.
And then I just know immediately what you don't have.
And by arranging the messages and then learning your audio,
order it makes that comparison completely simple.
If you have more complicated orderings--
and if you have some kind of more complicated structure,
it becomes much, much more difficult
to do a remote set comparison.
But if you have it in a linear order, it's like dead simple.
So just like compromise towards the simpler structure that's
easier to be optimal about.
But that is a problem.
And that if you're having-- like the original paper that
describes this said that it probably--
it was designed for one cluster within a data center.
So you'd have a DynamoDB instance that they said might
have 300 nodes.
Which is maybe a lot for one cluster in a data center.
But it's not a lot for a petapare network.
We want to have thousands and thousands of nodes.
So if you have thousands and thousands of nodes,
then just sending the vector clock really adds up.
Because it might just be like a public key and a sequence
number.
So that might be like 80 bytes.
But then if you're sending this for like 3,000 people,
that is like into like hundreds of kilobytes.
So that means like each time you connect,
you might send like half a megabyte of data both ways.
And if you reconnect and reconnect,
you could be sending like tens of megabytes a day
just to keep the network alive.
Like even if no messages are being sent.
So that's not really-- that's not very good at all.
But one of the other security scotterboat contributors,
Sel, Charles Lenher, came up with this idea
to skip some requests.
So what you do is you just remember the vector clock
that the other person sent you.
And then compare your new vector clock to the stored one
for that pair.
And then just don't mention all the things that haven't changed.
So if we meet on Sunday and we exchange news about Carol,
and then we meet each other again on Wednesday,
and neither of us have talked to Carol since then,
we just don't mention Carol.
And because we know that if the other person did,
they would mention her.
So that means that you can just leave out most of the vector
clock, and you just don't mention most of the things
that have changed-- that-- all the things that you think
probably haven't changed.
And then if you find out if some-- if the other person
does mention it, then you just reply with like your partial
figure clock of the things that didn't change.
So I had-- yeah, and this is really important because when
you have like people using pretty much any kind of application,
power law is really typical.
So you're really likely to have some users
that are like really active--
user every day or posting constantly.
You'll have like some users that are like daily a fair amount
of moderate users, and then like heaps and heaps of people
that only use it occasionally, or even signed up
and if you used it again.
And you don't want to be wasting bandwidth on people
that haven't done anything in a while.
So this simple technique allows you to completely cut out
all of that stuff.
And that basically gives you an end.
So basic Scuttlebutt, the message over here per connection
was like the messages plus the feeds.
And if no messages have changed, the messages might be 0,
but feeds could be thousands.
But secure Scuttlebutt is messages plus updated feeds.
And updated feeds could be much, much smaller number.
Usually it would be-- like if you reconnect frequently,
the number could be like will be close to 0.
If you reconnect months later, it will just be--
you might get individual users might have posted hundreds
of messages, but the overhead is just one
for that updated feed, which makes reconnections very cheap.
The only time you have to pay the whole send all of the feeds
is when you have a--
when the first time that 2PS connects.
Yes, that's for good.
And the latency complexity is just--
you're replicating in either one or two round trips.
So one round trip, if you've sent the whole clock,
and they then send the messages.
But if they send a part--
or if they don't-- or if the messages that you haven't
mentioned haven't updated, then it's one round trip.
And if you send a message--
if you send a partial vector--
if they send a partial vector clock,
and then you have to send one back, then it's two round trips.
But my background, since now basically improvising,
so I became interested in this because I was
living on a sailboat in New Zealand.
And I was used to--
my normal thing was not having very good internet.
At the first, when I first became interested in this,
I didn't actually have any internet in my boat.
And I was like, why can't that be--
why does that mean that I can't use my computer?
You should be able to use your computer.
I also grew up on a farm in New Zealand,
where the best internet we had was a satellite internet that
had a one second round trip, which is like--
it shouldn't really take that long for light to travel,
but it has lots of switching packets and that sort of stuff.
So I was really determined to--
latency is really a killer.
If you live in a fancy place that has fiber and that sort of stuff,
then latency, you might not be able to notice
that a couple of extra round trips might not be that bad.
But when latency gets bad, it gets really bad.
And if you have a design with that
sends a lot of packets back and forth,
then it's going to be really, really painful
to use in that situation.
So I was determined to have a constant number of round trips.
So one or two round trips, I think,
is about how much I can tolerate for a replication protocol.
Logarithmic round trips, not acceptable.
That's going to be really painful in many cases.
So the part three is simply I've arrived in comparison
to APFS.
I was sure people would ask about this.
So Secure Scuttlebutt basically optimizes for the worst case
in APFS.
So Secure Scuttlebutt is designed for long,
append-only chains.
And this would be the pathological case in APFS.
So they're trying to do completely opposite things.
But similar in that they both replicate data
without global consistency.
So they're kind of like an infrastructural role
for if you're building other peer-pair apps and so on.
So neither again, neither have any cryptocurrency or thing
directly built into it.
But if you're building stuff like that,
you could move your data around using a combination
of these things.
Secure Scuttlebutt streams updates in order per feed.
And IPFS has appointed to the latest message and works back.
And if you wanted to have it relatively efficient,
you would have some kind of tree or some sort of direct to route
finder things or just not have very deep structures,
have relatively shallow ones.
So IPFS is probably better for arbitrary partial data
sets like Wookiees and sort of static sites,
such things, or like directories of data and that sort of stuff.
Whereas SSB is designed specifically
for social applications with something strapped on the side.
So Secure Scuttlebutt is basically graph database
and IPFS is file system.
Yep, OK.
That took less long because I didn't
get to show you the animation stuff.
But that's it.
